newsitem.title: USA: NYMEX Hub natgas ends mostly lower on weak cash.
newsitem.headline: NYMEX Hub natgas ends mostly lower on weak cash.

text.p: NYMEX Henry Hub natgas futures mostly ended lower Friday in a moderate session, pressured the entire day by reports of crumbling cash prices and a flood of technical selling after an early break of support.
March tumbled 17.9 cents to close at $2.182 per million British thermal units. April settled 8.6 cents lower at $2.092. Others ended mixed, with some 1999s again up slightly.

"The fundamentals are bearish, and technically, we broke some key support. I think we could see (March) prices in the $1.90s soon," said one East Coast trader, adding he expected the "carnage" to continue on Monday.
The National Weather Service 6-10 day forecast released Friday expects the eastern half of the nation to range from normal to above-normal, while the West dips below-normal.

With little exteme weather on the horizon and the eastern stock surplus likely to grow more in next week's AGA data, few expected cash or futures to rally much near-term. Most agreed pressure on eastern utilities to trim bloated stocks will mount as winter draws to a close in the next six weeks.
Technical traders said March's close Friday below trendline support should mean a test of the Nov 5 low of $2.12. March resistance was seen in the low-$2.50s and then in the $2.70 and $2.80 area.

In the cash, weekend Gulf Coast prices skidded 10-15 cents Friday to the mid-$2.30s. Midcon pipes were off about a nickel to the $2.30-35 area. New York city gate gas was quoted more than 10 cents lower at about $2.90.
The 12-month Henry Hub strip fell five cents to $2.147. NYMEX said an estimated 33,830 Hub contracts traded, up from Thursday's revised tally of 21,794.
NYMEX Alberta and Permian natgas did not trade Friday.
On the KCBT, March finished 12.9 cents lower at $1.97, while deferreds ended down by two to 6.3 cents. The East/West spread narrowed by five cents to 21.2 cents (NYMEX premium).
